metadata.title: Two Views of the Battle of Trenton
metadata.author: Tamara Uhaze

caption.text: Leading into December of 1776, the Continental Army under the command of George Washington had suffered numerous losses to the British forcing them to retreat into Pennsylvania (Savas & Dameron, 2010). The tides turned on the morning of the 26th when Washington’s men defeated the Hessian forces at Trenton, followed by a victory in Princeton one week later on January 3rd, 1777. This map, drawn by William Faden, was published in April 1777, in London, and depicts the movement of both sides during these crucial battles.
caption.title: Introduction

caption.text: This second sketch, is of the Battle of Trenton, as witnessed by Hessian Lieutenant Andreas Wiederholdt, who was later captured by the Continental Army and provided information to Washington (Washington Crossing Park, 2024). Though both depicting the same event, and serving the same side, these two maps show a difference in priorities and cartographic style.

Wiederholdt’s sketch is looking closely at Trenton. There is less concern for surrounding roads and towns, and instead much more detail on the natural features. Wiederholdt provides detailed and colored woodlands, and even shades the Delaware River blue, preferring to highlight the landscape around the battle. In places this serves to show who had the high ground, and where the cover of trees was used in battle.
caption.title: The Narrow Focus

caption.text: In contrast, Faden’s map takes a broader view of the region. Of note is the inclusion of development, such as roads and towns (demarcated with churches), despite the fact that they were not involved in the movement of troops for the battles represented. This wider view allows Faden to showcase two areas of battle.
caption.title: The Wide View

caption.text: The title of Faden’s map makes clear that the events depicted occurred between December 26th 1776 and January 3rd, 1777.
caption.title: The Dates

caption.text: However, a look at the publication information shows that this was printed in April 1777, well after the events, and in London. This map benefits from hindsight, with Faden being able to illustrate multiple regiments and movements.

Faden’s map shows two sides in these battles. The British, represented in red, and the Continental Army, represented in blue. Though there is no key, the names of the generals are listed above their movements making this clear.
caption.title: The Question of Colors

caption.text: Interestingly, Wiederholdt’s sketch shows the Hessian forces in blue while Washington’s troops are colored in orange. Though again, there is no key to the colors, the textual information provided clarifies who is who.
If we look to a third document, a map of the Battle of Brandywine published in 1778, also by Faden, we can see a legend which separates the Hessian’s from the British.

A closer look at the notes shows that this map was originally drawn by a Hessian lieutenant, and only engraved by Faden. This suggests the Hessians continued to view themselves as separate from the British forces, in line with the wearing of their own uniforms and the flying of their own German flags (American Battlefield Trust, 2023).

Returning to Faden’s map of Trenton, the list of losses even shows confusion as to which Hessian commanders were at the battle, Anspach or von Lossberg, even while considering them part of the British forces (Maloy, 2018).

The larger view of Faden’s map shows a focus on the movement of whole regiments over the course of the week. Numerous marches and retreats are noted, and the main roads around Trenton and Princeton are colored with the paths of troops.
caption.title: Military Focus

caption.text: Alternately, Wiederhodlt’s sketch provides more information on the movements of each side during the battle of Trenton. Which ultimately gives more clarity on how the battle was won.

The descriptive legend on the right side gives insight into the location of important leaders, as well as the strategic movement of forces. When combined with the sketch, it is more clear what advantages each side had.
For instance, Washington’s location is demarcated with a V and we can see that he was positioned on the high-ground due to the shading Wiederhodlt uses to show elevations.

Both of these maps provide different insights into this crucial turning point of the Revolution. Wiederholdt’s sketch gives eyewitness detail of the Battle of Trenton, while Faden’s map shows the momentum that built through the week culminating in two decisive victories. They can also provide a look into the way Hessian soldiers viewed themselves as a third group on the battle field.
caption.title: Conclusion
